also reports memleaks):

```
==4065==    by 0x808044A: tcp_process_packet (in /home/martin/src/hackings/c-toxcore/auto_tox_many_tcp_test)
==4065==    by 0x8080592: do_confirmed_TCP (in /home/martin/src/hackings/c-toxcore/auto_tox_many_tcp_test)
==4065==    by 0x80807C9: do_TCP_connection (in /home/martin/src/hackings/c-toxcore/auto_tox_many_tcp_test)
==4065==    by 0x807771C: do_tcp_conns (in /home/martin/src/hackings/c-toxcore/auto_tox_many_tcp_test)
==4065==
==4065==
==4065== HEAP SUMMARY:
==4065==     in use at exit: 53,417,064 bytes in 1,378 blocks
==4065==   total heap usage: 41,229 allocs, 39,851 frees, 67,896,496 bytes allocated
==4065==

==4065==    definitely lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==4065==    indirectly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks

==4065==         suppressed: 0 bytes in 0 blocks

==4065==
==4065== For counts of detected and suppressed errors, rerun with: -v
==4065== Use --track-origins=yes to see where uninitialised values come from
==4065== ERROR SUMMARY: 1437 errors from 12 contexts (suppressed: 0 from 0)
```

comment_data.body: To clarify: the test didn't actually complete here (it seems never to when run with valgrind), but rather was killed, hence the "still reachable" memory.

@kpp that's probably the wrong fix, since it means we're creating an onion path to IP 0.0.0.0 with public key 000000..etc. as the first node. This is likely a bug, so making the error go away will hide that bug (if it is one). If it's not a bug, and we indeed intend to create an onion path starting with a non-existing node when we're using TCP, then zeroing out the memory makes sense, but not in those two places.
I've fixed all the valgrind issues and we now have a CI test that checks it.

title: valgrind reports "Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)"
